articles.headline: With 4 Deaths in Iran and More Cases on 3 Continents, Fears of Coronavirus Pandemic Rise
articles.snippet: Health officials called the surge in reported infections “very worrisome,” as cases soared in South Korea. Europe and North America reported a big uptick in infections.
articles.abstract: Health officials called the surge in reported infections “very worrisome,” as cases soared in South Korea. Europe and North America reported a big uptick in infections.
articles.lead_paragraph: Read live updates on the coronavirus outbreak here.
articles.byline: By Vivian Wang, Donald G. McNeil Jr., Farnaz Fassihi and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: Nevada Is Booming. But Not Everyone Is Feeling the Gains.
articles.snippet: In a state that has become a Democratic stronghold, housing prices have rebounded and Las Vegas is shattering visitor records.
articles.abstract: In a state that has become a Democratic stronghold, housing prices have rebounded and Las Vegas is shattering visitor records.
articles.lead_paragraph: HENDERSON, Nev. — The signs of Nevada’s resurgent economy are everywhere in this community outside Las Vegas, the fastest-growing city in one of the country’s fastest-growing states.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy and Roger Kisby

articles.headline: FreshDirect, After Broken Eggs and Angry Customers, Stages a Comeback
articles.snippet: Battling a troubled move and loss of shoppers’ trust, the New York online grocery service now contends with increased competition.
articles.abstract: Battling a troubled move and loss of shoppers’ trust, the New York online grocery service now contends with increased competition.
articles.lead_paragraph: About a year and a half ago, longtime patrons of the pioneering grocery delivery service FreshDirect started complaining that orders were arriving hours late. There were broken eggs and spoiled fruit. One customer reported that she had paid $200 for groceries — only to receive nothing but seltzer and a loaf of bread.
articles.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany

articles.headline: Federal Prosecutors Investigating Whether Boeing Pilot Lied to F.A.A.
articles.snippet: In questions before a grand jury, prosecutors have focused on whether a top pilot misled regulators about new flight control software in the 737 Max plane.
articles.abstract: In questions before a grand jury, prosecutors have focused on whether a top pilot misled regulators about new flight control software in the 737 Max plane.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors investigating Boeing are examining whether the company knowingly misled the Federal Aviation Administration while it was seeking the regulator’s approval for its 737 Max plane, according to two people familiar with the matter who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss an active inquiry.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: The Price of Wells Fargo’s Fake Account Scandal Grows by $3 Billion
articles.snippet: The bank reached a settlement with federal prosecutors and the Securities and Exchange Commission after abusing customers.
articles.abstract: The bank reached a settlement with federal prosecutors and the Securities and Exchange Commission after abusing customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo has agreed to pay $3 billion to settle criminal charges and a civil action stemming from its widespread mistreatment of customers in its community bank over a 14-year period, the Justice Department announced on Friday.
articles.byline: By Emily Flitter

articles.headline: Russia Is Said to Be Interfering to Aid Sanders in Democratic Primaries
articles.snippet: The nominal Democratic front-runner denounced Russia’s efforts to attack American democracy.
articles.abstract: The nominal Democratic front-runner denounced Russia’s efforts to attack American democracy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russia has been trying to intervene in the Democratic primaries to aid Senator Bernie Sanders, according to people familiar with the matter, and Mr. Sanders said on Friday that intelligence officials recently briefed him.
articles.byline: By Julian E. Barnes and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: Under O’Brien, N.S.C. Carries Out Trump’s Policy, but Doesn’t Develop It
articles.snippet: President Trump’s fourth national security adviser says he is restoring a neutral “process,” but the president’s tweets come first.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s fourth national security adviser says he is restoring a neutral “process,” but the president’s tweets come first.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Trump’s national security adviser, Robert C. O’Brien, convenes meetings with top National Security Council officials at the White House, he sometimes opens by distributing printouts of Mr. Trump’s latest tweets on the subject at hand.
articles.byline: By Michael Crowley and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: ‘We’re in a Petri Dish’: How a Coronavirus Ravaged a Cruise Ship
articles.snippet: More than three days passed before Japan imposed a quarantine. That delay and other missteps helped produce the largest outbreak of the virus beyond China.
articles.abstract: More than three days passed before Japan imposed a quarantine. That delay and other missteps helped produce the largest outbreak of the virus beyond China.
articles.lead_paragraph: YOKOHAMA, Japan — The captain came over the intercom early in the evening: A passenger who had left the ship nine days earlier had tested positive for the new coronavirus sweeping through China.
articles.byline: By Motoko Rich

articles.headline: Trump’s Efforts to Remove the Disloyal Heightens Unease Across His Administration
articles.snippet: As senior officials are shown the door, a new personnel chief orders a search for political appointees as well as career officials deemed insufficiently supportive of the president.
articles.abstract: As senior officials are shown the door, a new personnel chief orders a search for political appointees as well as career officials deemed insufficiently supportive of the president.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In some of the most critical corners of the Trump administration, officials show up for work now never entirely sure who will be there by the end of the evening — themselves included.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker

articles.headline: Digital Edits, a Paid Army: Bloomberg Is ‘Destroying Norms’ on Social Media
articles.snippet: His campaign is testing the boundaries of what platforms like Twitter and Facebook allow in politics. They’re having trouble coming up with an answer.
articles.abstract: His campaign is testing the boundaries of what platforms like Twitter and Facebook allow in politics. They’re having trouble coming up with an answer.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In the first few months of his presidential campaign, Michael R. Bloomberg has been as aggressive on social media as President Trump was four years ago. But with a lot more money to spend.
articles.byline: By Sheera Frenkel and Davey Alba

articles.headline: Same Goal, Different Playbook: Why Russia Would Support Trump and Sanders
articles.snippet: Vladimir Putin is eager both to take the sheen off U.S. democracy and for a counterpart who is less likely to challenge his territorial and nuclear ambitions.
articles.abstract: Vladimir Putin is eager both to take the sheen off U.S. democracy and for a counterpart who is less likely to challenge his territorial and nuclear ambitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: At first glance, it may seem contradictory that the nation’s intelligence agencies were telling Congress that President Vladimir V. Putin is presumably striving to get President Trump re-elected, while also warning Senator Bernie Sanders of evidence that he is the Russian president’s favorite Democrat.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Bernie Sanders Wins Nevada Caucuses, Strengthening His Primary Lead
articles.snippet: His triumph will provide a burst of momentum that may make it difficult for the still-fractured moderate wing of the Democratic Party to slow his march to the nomination.
articles.abstract: His triumph will provide a burst of momentum that may make it difficult for the still-fractured moderate wing of the Democratic Party to slow his march to the nomination.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Senator Bernie Sanders claimed a major victory in the Nevada caucuses on Saturday that demonstrated his broad appeal in the first racially diverse state in the presidential primary race and established him as the clear front-runner for the Democratic nomination.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: How a Neighbors’ Feud in Paradise Launched an International Rape Case
articles.snippet: The fashion executive Peter Nygard has clashed for years with his neighbor in the Bahamas, the billionaire Louis Bacon. The latest development is a lawsuit saying Mr. Nygard sexually exploited teenage girls.
articles.abstract: The fashion executive Peter Nygard has clashed for years with his neighbor in the Bahamas, the billionaire Louis Bacon. The latest development is a lawsuit saying Mr. Nygard sexually exploited teenage girls.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Bahamian pleasure palace featured a faux Mayan temple, sculptures of smoke-breathing snakes and a disco with a stripper pole. The owner, Peter Nygard, a Canadian fashion executive, showed off his estate on TV shows like “Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous” and threw loud beachfront parties, reveling in the company of teenage girls and young women.
articles.byline: By Kim Barker, Catherine Porter and Grace Ashford

articles.headline: How Bernie Sanders Dominated in Nevada
articles.snippet: A multiracial coalition brought the senator’s long-promised political revolution to vivid life, for perhaps the first time in the 2020 race.
articles.abstract: A multiracial coalition brought the senator’s long-promised political revolution to vivid life, for perhaps the first time in the 2020 race.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — They showed up to Desert Pines High School in Tío Bernie T-shirts to caucus on Saturday morning, motivated by the idea of free college tuition, “Medicare for all” and the man making those promises: a 78-year-old white senator from Vermont. To dozens of mostly working-class Latinos, Bernie Sanders seemed like one of their own, a child of immigrants who understands what it means to be seen as a perpetual outsider.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Medina and Astead W. Herndon

articles.headline: Teaching Children How to Reverse an Overdose
articles.snippet: In rural Carter County, Tenn., health officials have embraced a strategy for stemming addiction: Teaching children as young as 6 how to administer Narcan, a nasal spray that can stop an opioid overdose from being fatal.
articles.abstract: In rural Carter County, Tenn., health officials have embraced a strategy for stemming addiction: Teaching children as young as 6 how to administer Narcan, a nasal spray that can stop an opioid overdose from being fatal.
articles.lead_paragraph: ELIZABETHTON, Tenn. — Shortly after his first-grade class let out for the day, Nash Kitchens sat with a dozen other young children at a library and played a murder mystery game that had a surprising plot twist.
articles.byline: By Dan Levin

articles.headline: Europe Confronts Coronavirus as Italy Battles an Eruption of Cases
articles.snippet: The country announced more than 150 cases, many in the densely populated region around Milan, as officials closed schools and canceled Venice’s carnival celebrations.
articles.abstract: The country announced more than 150 cases, many in the densely populated region around Milan, as officials closed schools and canceled Venice’s carnival celebrations.
articles.lead_paragraph: CASALPUSTERLENGO, Italy — Europe confronted its first major outbreak of the coronavirus as an eruption of more than 150 cases in Italy prompted officials on Sunday to lock down at least 10 towns, close schools in major cities and cancel sporting events and cultural touchstones, including the end of the Venice carnival.
articles.byline: By Jason Horowitz and Elisabetta Povoledo

articles.headline: Intuit Is Expected to Buy Credit Karma in $7 Billion Deal
articles.snippet: A start-up known for providing free credit scores, Credit Karma is set to avoid the I.P.O. market and instead sell to an established financial firm.
articles.abstract: A start-up known for providing free credit scores, Credit Karma is set to avoid the I.P.O. market and instead sell to an established financial firm.
articles.lead_paragraph: Intuit, the home of TurboTax and Mint, is nearing a deal to buy Credit Karma, a start-up that grew to fame by offering consumers free access to their credit scores, for about $7 billion in cash and stock, two people briefed on the matter said on Sunday.
articles.byline: By Nathaniel Popper, Michael J. de la Merced and Ron Lieber

articles.headline: Gunmakers Battle ‘Trump Slump’ With a Softer Sales Pitch
articles.snippet: The firearms industry is moving beyond macho marketing, testing a more inclusive strategy to counter sagging sales.
articles.abstract: The firearms industry is moving beyond macho marketing, testing a more inclusive strategy to counter sagging sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — It was like any other convention in this city of neon and slot machines, except for all the guns.
articles.byline: By Tiffany Hsu

articles.headline: Streaming TV’s Boom Is a Mixed Blessing for Some Hollywood Writers
articles.snippet: The glut of shows has created more opportunities, but short seasons and unpredictable schedules have made life tricky.
articles.abstract: The glut of shows has created more opportunities, but short seasons and unpredictable schedules have made life tricky.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It seemed like a good deal. At first.
articles.byline: By Rachel Abrams

articles.headline: D.C. Prosecutors’ Tensions With Justice Dept. Began Long Before Stone Sentencing
articles.snippet: Months of strain date back to the investigation into the former F.B.I. official Andrew McCabe and growing fears of political interference.
articles.abstract: Months of strain date back to the investigation into the former F.B.I. official Andrew McCabe and growing fears of political interference.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the days before they filed the sentencing recommendation for President Trump’s friend Roger J. Stone Jr. that helped plunge the Justice Department into turmoil, the prosecutors on the case felt under siege.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: Sanders Looks to Knock Out Biden as Pressure Builds on Democrats
articles.snippet: The primary race is entering a critical nine-day stretch that could effectively determine the nomination as candidates face a debate, the South Carolina primary and Super Tuesday contests.
articles.abstract: The primary race is entering a critical nine-day stretch that could effectively determine the nomination as candidates face a debate, the South Carolina primary and Super Tuesday contests.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Energized by his landslide victory in the Nevada caucuses, Senator Bernie Sanders turned his focus to President Trump on Sunday while his campaign made plans to try to win the coming South Carolina primary and amass an insurmountable delegate lead on Super Tuesday next week.
articles.byline: By Sydney Ember and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: As the Start-Up Boom Deflates, Tech Is Humbled
articles.snippet: Layoffs. Shutdowns. Uncertainty. After a decade of prosperity, many hot young companies are facing a reckoning.
articles.abstract: Layoffs. Shutdowns. Uncertainty. After a decade of prosperity, many hot young companies are facing a reckoning.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Over the past decade, technology start-ups grew so quickly that they couldn’t hire people fast enough.
articles.byline: By Erin Griffith

articles.headline: As Trump Barricades the Border, Legal Immigration Is Starting to Plunge
articles.snippet: President Trump’s border wall is beginning to rise, but a thick curtain of policy changes is more responsible for suppressing the flow of immigrants into the country.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s border wall is beginning to rise, but a thick curtain of policy changes is more responsible for suppressing the flow of immigrants into the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s immigration policies — from travel bans and visa restrictions to refugee caps and asylum changes — have begun to deliver on a longstanding goal: Legal immigration has fallen more than 11 percent and a steeper drop is looming.
articles.byline: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs

articles.headline: U.S. Stocks Plunge as Coronavirus Crisis Spreads
articles.snippet: As outbreaks spread outside China, spiking in Italy and South Korea, investors are growing increasingly concerned about a global economic slowdown.
articles.abstract: As outbreaks spread outside China, spiking in Italy and South Korea, investors are growing increasingly concerned about a global economic slowdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors in the United States have mostly shrugged off the impact of the coronavirus ravaging China. That changed on Monday, when news of the outbreak’s spread drove them to sell stocks — at a furious pace.
articles.byline: By Matt Phillips, Jason Horowitz and Choe Sang-Hun
